content:
In simplicial sets there is an 'interchange' map
h:(A×B)∗(C×D)→(A∗C)×(B∗D)h : (A \times B) * (C \times D) \to (A * C) \times (B * D)h:(A×B)∗(C×D)→(A∗C)×(B∗D)
given by
h=(πA∗πC,πB∗πD)h = (\pi_A * \pi_C, \pi_B * \pi_D)h=(πA​∗πC​,πB​∗πD​)
where ×\times× is the cartesian product and ∗*∗ is the join.
Is it a monomorphism? How can I see that it is or is not? I know the criterion of monomorphism (left-cancellative) but I don't know how to check if it holds here.

Nasos Evangelou-Oost said:

In simplicial sets there is an 'interchange' map
i:(A×B)∗(C×D)→(A∗C)×(B∗D)i : (A \times B) * (C \times D) \to (A * C) \times (B * D)i:(A×B)∗(C×D)→(A∗C)×(B∗D)
given by
i=(πA∗πC,πB∗πD)i = (\pi_A * \pi_C, \pi_B * \pi_D)i=(πA​∗πC​,πB​∗πD​)
where ×\times× is the cartesian product and ∗*∗ is the join.
Is it a monomorphism? How can I see that it is or is not? I know the criterion of monomorphism (left-cancellative) but I don't know how to check if it holds here.

Ok, now I'm thinking it is a mono but I'm not completely confident in my reasoning: If f,g:Q→(A×B)∗(C×D)f,g : Q \to (A \times B) * (C \times D)f,g:Q→(A×B)∗(C×D) and x∈Qnx \in Q_nx∈Qn​ then since (X∗Y)n=∐i+j+1=nXi×Yj(X * Y)_n = \coprod_{i+j+1=n} X_i \times Y_j(X∗Y)n​=∐i+j+1=n​Xi​×Yj​,
f(x):=(f(x)i,f(x)j)=((f(x)ia,f(x)ib),(f(x)jc,f(x)jd))∈(A×B)i×(C×D)jf(x) := (f(x)_i, f(x)_j) = ((f(x)_i^a,f(x)_i^b), (f(x)_j^c,f(x)_j^d)) \in (A \times B)_i \times (C \times D)_jf(x):=(f(x)i​,f(x)j​)=((f(x)ia​,f(x)ib​),(f(x)jc​,f(x)jd​))∈(A×B)i​×(C×D)j​
for some i,ji,ji,j with i+j+1=ni + j + 1 = ni+j+1=n.
Now h(f(x))=((f(x)ia,f(x)jc),(f(x)ib),f(x)jd))∈(A∗C)n×(B∗D)nh(f(x)) = ((f(x)_i^a,f(x)_j^c),(f(x)_i^b), f(x)_j^d)) \in (A * C)_n \times (B * D)_nh(f(x))=((f(x)ia​,f(x)jc​),(f(x)ib​),f(x)jd​))∈(A∗C)n​×(B∗D)n​.
So if h(f(x))=h(g(x))h(f(x)) = h(g(x))h(f(x))=h(g(x)) then f(x)=g(x)f(x) = g(x)f(x)=g(x) since the dimensions and components must match, so hhh is a monomorphism?
